Literature Review: The concept of the preferred retinal locus (PRL) has gained significant attention in the field of ophthalmology, particularly in relation to patients with macular diseases. This literature review aims to explore the current understanding of PRLs, their development, measurement, and implications for visual function and clinical practice.The PRL is defined as an eccentric retinal area that individuals with central vision loss consistently use for fixation and other visual tasks [1]. This adaptation occurs when the fovea, the central part of the retina responsible for high-acuity vision, is damaged due to conditions such as age-related macular degeneration (AMD) or Stargardt disease [2]. The development of a PRL is crucial for maintaining visual function in these patients, as it allows them to utilize relatively healthy areas of the retina for visual tasks.Identifying and measuring the PRL is a complex process that requires careful consideration of various factors. Traditional methods include fundus photography, scanning laser ophthalmoscopy (SLO), and microperimetry [3]. However, these techniques often provide only a monocular assessment of the PRL, which may not fully represent the patient's visual experience in real-world binocular conditions. Recent studies have emphasized the importance of evaluating PRLs under binocular viewing conditions to gain a more comprehensive understanding of visual function [4].The development of PRLs is not fully understood, but several hypotheses have been proposed. One theory suggests that PRLs develop in retinal areas with the highest remaining sensitivity [5]. Another hypothesis posits that PRLs form in locations that optimize reading performance, often to the left of the scotoma in languages read from left to right [6]. Additionally, some researchers argue that multiple PRLs may develop for different visual tasks, challenging the notion of a single, fixed PRL [7].An important question in PRL research is whether it becomes the new reference point for the ocular motor system. Studies have shown that patients with established PRLs demonstrate oculomotor adaptations, such as changes in saccade patterns and fixation stability [8]. However, the extent to which the PRL fully replaces the fovea as the oculomotor reference point remains debatable and may vary among individuals.The functional implications of PRLs are significant for patients with central vision loss. PRLs can impact various aspects of visual function, including reading speed, face recognition, and overall quality of life [9]. The location and stability of the PRL can greatly influence these outcomes, with more stable PRLs generally associated with better visual performance. However, the relationship between PRL characteristics and functional outcomes is complex and not always straightforward.From a clinical perspective, understanding PRLs is crucial for developing effective rehabilitation strategies for patients with macular diseases. Techniques such as eccentric viewing training and perceptual learning have shown promise in improving PRL use and visual function [10]. However, the optimal approach to PRL rehabilitation remains a subject of ongoing research, with factors such as PRL location, fixation stability, and individual patient characteristics all playing important roles.Despite the significant progress in PRL research, several challenges and limitations persist. The current definition of PRL may be incomplete, particularly in its consideration of binocular viewing conditions. Most studies have focused on monocular PRLs, potentially overlooking important aspects of real-world visual function. Additionally, the dynamic nature of PRLs and their potential to change over time or with different visual tasks complicates their assessment and management.In conclusion, the concept of the preferred retinal locus is central to our understanding of visual adaptation in patients with macular diseases. While significant progress has been made in identifying, measuring, and utilizing PRLs for clinical purposes, many questions remain unanswered. Future research should focus on developing more comprehensive methods for assessing PRLs under binocular conditions, exploring the mechanisms of PRL development and adaptation, and refining rehabilitation strategies to optimize visual function in patients with central vision loss. As our understanding of PRLs continues to evolve, it holds the potential to significantly improve the quality of life for individuals affected by macular diseases.
